results.title: Reading planet
results.creator_credit: Pawel Kuczynski, Study Sources Unlimited and H G Simons Productions
results.brief_description: Prism a young alien from the planet Reading is given the task of improving the reading skills of five earth students. Through their various adventures the audience is introduced to techniques such as deriving meaning from context, visualisation, etc.

results.title: Individual progress in reading (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Edward Milner, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Reading Development”.
Examines the provision for individual progress in reading at two American schools. Two reading improvement specialists are seen operating different aspects of their respective reading programs. The schools are located on airbases in Oxfordshire.

results.title: Context, concept and structure (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Reading Development”.
Shows 7-9 year old children from Saffron Green First School, Boreham Wood, England, involved in activities designed to develop intermediate reading skills. Includes sentence building with pictures and phrases; sentence building without pictures; editing a story based on existing sentences; understanding anaphora, structuring an attributes matrix; group working on a cloze passage.

results.title: The Enormous turnip
results.creator_credit: Lorne Magory, Jenny Reeks, Pickwick Video and Ladybird
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Read it yourself”.
Nerys Hughes presents the well-known children’s story, “The Enormous Turnip”. An old man planted some turnip seeds, but one of the seeds grows and grows, till it is so enormous no one could harvest it - at least, not until help came. The video comes with the picture book of the same story so young viewers can both watch and read the story. The video concludes with a talk on turnips, a song about planting turnips and some related gardening and craft activities for children.

group_works.title: Bermuda, Bahama, Jamaica
group_works.creator_credit: Peter Teneyck and Video Trip Corporation

results.title: Bermuda, Bahama, Jamaica
results.creator_credit: Peter Teneyck and Video Trip Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rand McNally video visit trips”.
Tricia Springer takes you on a tour of three exotic ports of call in the Caribbean. Behind the picture postcard beauty of Bermuda is an island filled with activity, and British tradition. Turquoise waters and natural beauty await you in the Bahamas, which has a vital night life of discos, casinos and Las Vegas style shows. Jamaica is truly West Indian and is permeated by the calypso and reggae beats. Included are bonus tips on getting there, accommodation, food, special events, clothing and climate.

results.title: Women: three views
results.creator_credit: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
Interviews with three Aboriginal women who have chosen to be activists in the struggle for their peoples’ rights. Mum Shirl has been an activist since the late sixties, including initiating the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in the early seventies. Since then she has become disillusioned with political processes in Australia and now chooses to work directly with Aboriginal people in prisons. Marcia Langton works for the Central Lands Council in Alice Springs and she talks passionately on behalf of Aboriginal peoples’ struggles for land rights and dignity. Maryanne Bin-Sallik works within government departments using established political means to argue for the rights of Aborigines. Though choosing very different ways to express their activism, we see that all three women are united in their commitment to work towards an autonomous and central role for Aborigines in Australian politics and culture.

results.title: Sacred sites
results.creator_credit: Richard Guthrie, Commonwealth Dept of Aboriginal Affairs and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Rainbow serpent”.
Bob Maza narrates this exploration of the Australian Aborigine’s relationship to his sacred sites. Several sites are visited with their guardians who explain the importance of maintaining the sites and protecting them from the tourist, mining and agricultural industries. Sites visited include, Merella Cave, W.A., Uluru, Alice Springs, Guru Guru Cave, W.A. and Milbrodale, N.S.W. There are also extensive interviews with Charles Perkins.
